name: Chloe Bernstein
clarity_response: An app that gives you 3-5 curated, filtered NYC activity recommendations so you don't have to research across six platforms.
strongest_line: Free to get started. No account required to browse your first shortlist.
what_feels_off: The curation section is genuinely useful but it's long. By the time I get to it, I've already decided. It might work better as a collapsible or tooltip for skeptics, not a full section everyone reads.
objections: Still no launch date, but '48 hours' is actually a promise I can hold them to. That's better.
gut_reaction: This is the clearest version yet. 'Free to get started' answered the one question I had. I'd sign up right now.
unanswered_questions: Group shortlist features? Can multiple people input preferences?
price_reaction: Free tier is great. Would pay for premium if recs are consistently good.

name: Aaliyah Johnson
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist — 3-5 personalized picks filtered by your interests, schedule, and budget instead of a wall of results.
strongest_line: Share it with your group chat or keep it to yourself.
what_feels_off: The new example cards are way more interesting — Bronx textile show, Taiwanese pop-up, site-specific theater. None of these feel like things I'd have found myself. That's exactly the point.
objections: The curation transparency section is good for skeptics but I didn't need it. Might slow down buyers like me.
gut_reaction: This is a clear upgrade. The 'share it with your group chat' line is exactly what I needed to see. I'd sign up and immediately think about sending it to my friends.
unanswered_questions: Can multiple people in my group input their preferences for a combined shortlist?
price_reaction: Would pay. Free to start is exactly right.

name: Mei-Lin Wu
clarity_response: A personalized NYC activity shortlist — set filters, get 3-5 quality recommendations including genuinely hard-to-find events.
strongest_line: Free to get started. No account required to browse your first shortlist.
what_feels_off: The 'how we decide' section is thorough but dense. I'd skim it. The example cards do more work in fewer words.
objections: The curation transparency is great but might be too long for the page. Could be a FAQ or separate page.
gut_reaction: Best version so far. The example cards are finally believable — a pop-up dinner that sells out by Wednesday, site-specific theater not on Eventbrite. That's the product I want.
unanswered_questions: Group preferences? Launch timeline for my borough (Midtown East)?
price_reaction: Would happily pay after trying the free tier.

name: Omar Farouk
clarity_response: NYC event shortlist app — curated picks for your interests and budget, including genuinely obscure events not on major platforms.
strongest_line: Share it with your group chat or keep it to yourself.
what_feels_off: The 'how we decide' section — I appreciate the transparency but it slows me down. I was ready to sign up after the example cards.
objections: Minor: the 48-hour shortlist promise — is that realistic if I'm the first person in my neighborhood?
gut_reaction: The group chat line got me. That's my use case. I'm the one sending options to everyone. This finally acknowledges that.
unanswered_questions: Multi-person preference input? Which neighborhoods are live?
price_reaction: Free to start is perfect. Would pay for premium.

name: Tamika Harris
clarity_response: An NYC event curation tool that surfaces 3-5 genuinely worth-it activities based on your filters — including things you wouldn't find on Eventbrite.
strongest_line: Get your first shortlist →
what_feels_off: Nothing significant. This is the strongest version of the copy I've seen.
objections: The 48-hour shortlist is a nice commitment. I just want it to actually deliver.
gut_reaction: I subscribed to 4 newsletters that don't do what this promises to do. I'd sign up immediately.
unanswered_questions: Newsletter or app? iOS or Android? Murray Hill coverage?
price_reaction: Free to start is the right entry point. Would pay for accuracy.

name: Keiko Yamamoto
clarity_response: A curated NYC shortlist of 3-5 activities — filtered by interests, budget, and schedule, with events you wouldn't easily find elsewhere.
strongest_line: Free to get started. No account required to browse your first shortlist.
what_feels_off: Still no date-night framing. The example cards include a pop-up dinner which could be a date, but it's not positioned that way. As someone trying to find couple activities, this still feels slightly solo-oriented.
objections: Couple/date framing still missing. Would want to know if it works for two-person scenarios.
gut_reaction: Strong. The free tier removes my hesitation. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Date/couple use case? Can two people both contribute preferences?
price_reaction: Free tier is right. Would pay for a joint couple plan.

name: Liam O'Brien
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist that curates genuinely hard-to-find activities — not just filtered Eventbrite listings.
strongest_line: Not on Eventbrite.
what_feels_off: The 'how we decide' section is probably necessary for skeptics but it's 3 paragraphs that interrupt the flow. I'd have signed up before reaching it.
objections: The curation section length — fine for skeptics, slows down buyers.
gut_reaction: The new example cards alone upgraded this from a maybe to a yes. 'Not on Eventbrite' is a genuinely strong proof point.
unanswered_questions: When exactly does early access open? Which neighborhoods are covered first?
price_reaction: Would pay. Free start is smart.

name: Jenna Liu
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist — personalized, 3-5 picks, including events not on major platforms.
strongest_line: Free to get started. No account required to browse your first shortlist.
what_feels_off: The site-specific theater example — 5 remaining tickets feels very manufactured. Scarcity signals can read as fake. The Taiwanese pop-up with a reservation deadline feels more real.
objections: Scarcity cues like '5 remaining tickets' can feel like fake urgency. Make sure they're accurate.
gut_reaction: Much better. The free-to-start removes any hesitation. Would sign up immediately.
unanswered_questions: Which neighborhoods are live? Williamsburg coverage?
price_reaction: Free tier to start. Would pay later.

name: Ethan Nakamura
clarity_response: An NYC activity shortlist that surfaces 3-5 personalized picks — including genuinely obscure events not on Eventbrite — based on your filters.
strongest_line: Not on Eventbrite.
what_feels_off: The 'how we decide' section is useful but slightly corporate in tone. The rest of the page is conversational. This section reads like a product spec.
objections: Tone inconsistency in the curation section vs the rest of the page.
gut_reaction: Significant upgrade. The example cards are the most convincing I've seen. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Bushwick coverage? iOS or Android? Newsletter format?
price_reaction: Would pay after free trial proves the recs.

name: Lucia Ferraro
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist — filtered by interests and budget, including genuinely hard-to-find events, shareable with your group.
strongest_line: Share it with your group chat or keep it to yourself.
what_feels_off: As an event coordinator, I know the Navy Yard. Site-specific theater there is plausible. The Bronx textile show — if that's real, this product is legit. If it's invented for the page, that's a trust problem when the product launches.
objections: The examples better be real. Invented example cards would be a betrayal when users see the actual product.
gut_reaction: The share-with-group-chat line made this product click for me. I'd sign up and immediately share the shortlist with my planning group.
unanswered_questions: Are the example cards real events? Multi-person preference input?
price_reaction: Free to start is right. Would pay for group features.

name: Theo Papadopoulos
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity shortlist — 3-5 filtered picks including things not on major platforms.
strongest_line: Not on Eventbrite.
what_feels_off: The curation transparency section is good but breaks the page rhythm. The rest of the page flows; this section stops and explains. Might work better as expandable content.
objections: Section flow — the curation explanation interrupts a landing page that was moving fast.
gut_reaction: Strong. Would sign up. The free tier removes any remaining friction.
unanswered_questions: Launch timing, Park Slope coverage.
price_reaction: Free to start is smart. Would pay for premium.

name: Danielle Brooks
clarity_response: A curated NYC shortlist of 3-5 activities — filtered, personalized, and including events not easily found elsewhere.
strongest_line: Free to get started. No account required to browse your first shortlist.
what_feels_off: Still no couple/date framing. The pop-up dinner could be positioned as date-night but it's not. Small miss.
objections: Couple activities still not addressed. Minor — wouldn't stop me signing up.
gut_reaction: The free tier and the new example cards are the right moves. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Couple/date use case, DUMBO coverage.
price_reaction: Free to start. Would pay after seeing quality.

name: Elena Petrov
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist app — filtered picks including genuinely obscure events, shareable with your group.
strongest_line: Share it with your group chat or keep it to yourself.
what_feels_off: The Taiwanese pop-up in Crown Heights — I live in Harlem. That's a real distance. I want to know if the location filter actually keeps things close.
objections: Geographic relevance — Crown Heights pop-up isn't near Harlem. Does the distance filter actually work by neighborhood?
gut_reaction: The group chat line got me. That's how we plan. I'd send this shortlist to my crew and see what they think.
unanswered_questions: Harlem coverage, neighborhood proximity filtering, launch date.
price_reaction: Free to start is perfect. Would pay small amount monthly.

name: Amira Khalil
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity shortlist — personalized and filtered, including things not on major platforms.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The curation transparency section is interesting but I didn't need it. I was sold by the example cards.
objections: Non-standard schedule — irregular hours. Does 'when are you free' handle any day of the week?
gut_reaction: Upgraded from V2. The example cards are actually believable now. I'd sign up and share with my spin class regulars.
unanswered_questions: Mid-week event coverage, Park Slope area coverage.
price_reaction: Free to start. Would pay.

name: Darius Jackson
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist that surfaces 3-5 genuinely obscure activities — not just filtered Eventbrite — based on your interests and location.
strongest_line: Not on Eventbrite.
what_feels_off: The Bronx textile show — if this is real, it's impressive. But as someone in Flatbush, the distance matters. I need to know the distance filter actually prioritizes nearby.
objections: The example cards are all over the map geographically. I need proximity to actually work.
gut_reaction: Yes. This finally proves the product can find things I genuinely wouldn't have found. 'Not on Eventbrite' is the key line. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Flatbush/outer Brooklyn coverage, proximity accuracy.
price_reaction: Free to start. Would pay $5-8 if it works.

name: Natasha Ivanova
clarity_response: A curated shortlist of 3-5 NYC events — personalized, including genuinely hard-to-find things, shareable.
strongest_line: Making 'something different' the easier choice.
what_feels_off: The 'how we decide' section is good but long. The people who need it most (skeptics) are also the people most likely to be put off by a wall of explanation. Could be tighter.
objections: Section length. The rest of the page flows fast; this stops it.
gut_reaction: I want to be the person who finds cool things. This product promises that. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: SoHo coverage, how the recommendations are delivered (app/email?).
price_reaction: Free to start is right. Would pay.

name: Marcus Thompson
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist that sources from outside Eventbrite — mailing lists, venue newsletters, artist accounts — and filters for quality.
strongest_line: We source from everywhere Eventbrite doesn't. Gallery mailing lists, venue newsletters, artist Instagram accounts, community boards, local organizer networks.
what_feels_off: As a bartender I know the LES scene well. The example cards — a Bronx textile show, a Crown Heights pop-up, Navy Yard theater — are all genuinely not things I'd have already known about. That's the real test and these pass it.
objections: The sourcing section names 'artist Instagram accounts' — so they do use Instagram, just not your social profile. That distinction could be clearer.
gut_reaction: These examples actually convinced me. If the real product surfaces things like this, I'm interested. That's what I've been waiting for.
unanswered_questions: LES-specific coverage, how many events per shortlist, frequency.
price_reaction: Free to try. Would pay if it shows me things I genuinely didn't know.

name: Morgan Reilly
clarity_response: A curated NYC shortlist of 3-5 activities — filtered by interests, budget, and schedule including genuinely non-obvious options.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The example cards are all evening activities — a pop-up dinner at 7:30pm, theater on weekends. I want daytime and morning options. The site doesn't mention time-of-day filtering.
objections: Daytime / morning filtering still not addressed. Are there daytime options in the shortlist?
gut_reaction: Good upgrade. The new examples are more believable. Would sign up.
unanswered_questions: Daytime / morning event coverage, Murray Hill area.
price_reaction: Free to start. Would pay.

name: Yusuf Abdi
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist that sources from outside major platforms — mailing lists, artist accounts, community boards — and filters for quality.
strongest_line: We source from everywhere Eventbrite doesn't.
what_feels_off: As a restaurant manager, I already get venue newsletters and know the scene. But the Bronx textile show and the Navy Yard theater — those I genuinely didn't know about. That's the point.
objections: The sourcing section is compelling. If the real product is as broad as this implies, it would surface things even industry insiders miss.
gut_reaction: Changed my mind from V2. The sourcing transparency and the genuinely obscure example cards convinced me this could surface things I don't already know. I'd try it.
unanswered_questions: Flatbush area coverage, frequency of shortlists.
price_reaction: Would try free tier. Would pay if it shows me something new.

name: Gabrielle Moreau
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity shortlist — 3-5 filtered picks, shareable with your group, including things not on Eventbrite.
strongest_line: Share it with your group chat or keep it to yourself.
what_feels_off: Nothing major. This is the version of the page I wanted to see from the start.
objections: Still curious: can multiple people in the group input their preferences for a combined shortlist? 'Share the shortlist' is good but 'build the shortlist together' would be next level.
gut_reaction: Finally. The group chat line is what made this feel real for me. I'd sign up immediately and share the first shortlist with my friends.
unanswered_questions: Multi-person preference input, Chelsea coverage.
price_reaction: Free to start is perfect. Would pay for group features.

name: Fatima Al-Hassan
clarity_response: An NYC shortlist of 3-5 curated activities — filtered by interests and schedule, including genuinely obscure options.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: Solo-friendly framing is still just a checkbox in Step 1. As a recently single person I want to feel like a primary use case, not an accommodation. The examples all feel either solo or group-neutral.
objections: Solo and 'good for meeting new people' framing still thin. I want to feel like the product knows people use this alone.
gut_reaction: Better than V2. The free tier removes hesitation. I'd sign up even though the solo use case isn't front and center.
unanswered_questions: Solo-friendly events, activities where you can meet people, East Village coverage.
price_reaction: Free to start. Would pay small amount.

name: Aisha Rahman
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist — 3-5 personalized picks including hard-to-find events, shareable with your group.
strongest_line: Share it with your group chat or keep it to yourself.
what_feels_off: Very little. The new example cards and the group-chat line are exactly what this page needed.
objections: Minor: still curious about Fort Greene coverage.
gut_reaction: I'd sign up right now. This finally speaks to how I actually find plans — via group text. Sold.
unanswered_questions: Fort Greene coverage, how often shortlists are sent.
price_reaction: Free to start. Would pay.

name: Jake Rosenberg
clarity_response: An NYC event shortlist that sources from beyond Eventbrite and filters for quality — 3-5 personalized picks.
strongest_line: We source from everywhere Eventbrite doesn't.
what_feels_off: The sourcing section is detailed and I appreciate it. But it implicitly admits the product is labor-intensive. How do they scale that? Gallery mailing lists and community boards require human effort. I wonder about consistency.
objections: Scalability of the sourcing model — is this sustainable or will quality drop as they grow?
gut_reaction: The new examples finally prove discovery, not just curation. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Park Slope coverage, scalability of sourcing, how often lists update.
price_reaction: Free to start. Would pay if quality holds.

name: Renée Dubois
clarity_response: A curated NYC activity shortlist — filtered to your interests and budget, sourced beyond Eventbrite, shareable.
strongest_line: Stop ending up at the same place again.
what_feels_off: The pop-up dinner is in Crown Heights, the theater is at Navy Yard, the art show is in the Bronx. All across the city. I need the distance filter to actually keep things close to Washington Heights.
objections: Geographic scatter of example cards. I need to trust the proximity filter works.
gut_reaction: Good. The free tier and the group chat line are the right moves. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Washington Heights / Inwood coverage, proximity filter accuracy.
price_reaction: Free to start. Would pay small amount.

name: Andre Williams
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist sourced from beyond Eventbrite — filtered by preferences and behavior, no social media required.
strongest_line: We source from everywhere Eventbrite doesn't. Gallery mailing lists, venue newsletters, artist Instagram accounts, community boards, local organizer networks.
what_feels_off: The 'How We Decide' section is exactly what I needed. It's the first time a product has told me specifically how they source and what quality means. I still have a small residual question: what is the quality bar exactly — is 'would we go ourselves' really a standard, or is it marketing?
objections: The quality standard 'would we go ourselves' is better than nothing but still subjective. What calibrates their taste to mine?
gut_reaction: The sourcing section moved me from neutral to interested. I have a private Google Maps list because I don't trust external curation. This is the first product that's explained its methodology in a way I can evaluate. I'd try it.
unanswered_questions: Calibration of taste between curators and users. Is there any editorial transparency (who's doing this)?
price_reaction: Would pay if quality proves out.

name: Kira Johansson
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist — sourced beyond major platforms, filtered for quality, no social media profile required.
strongest_line: No social media profile. No influencer feed. No account required to browse.
what_feels_off: The quiet/solo-friendly callout is still just one line in Step 1. The example cards don't show a solo/quiet option. A site-specific theater could be quiet but it's positioned as a group event.
objections: The solo/quiet framing needs to be in the example cards, not just the category list. Show me what a quiet evening looks like in the shortlist.
gut_reaction: Better than V2. The sourcing section shows they're not just scraping Eventbrite. The Bronx textile show is genuinely the kind of thing I'd want to know about. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: What does a quiet/solo shortlist look like? Williamsburg coverage.
price_reaction: Would pay if quality is real.

name: Adrienne Cole
clarity_response: An NYC event curation tool that sources from beyond major platforms, applies an explicit quality bar, and learns from your skip/save behavior — no social profile needed.
strongest_line: We source from everywhere Eventbrite doesn't. Gallery mailing lists, venue newsletters, artist Instagram accounts, community boards, local organizer networks.
what_feels_off: As a UX researcher: the 'how we decide' section is the right move and finally tells me something specific. 'Would we go ourselves' is still soft as a quality standard but it's better than nothing. The behavior signal ('what you skip') is a real and credible mechanism.
objections: The quality bar is still somewhat subjective. 'Is the organizer credible' — how is credibility defined? This is better than V2 but not fully satisfying.
gut_reaction: This is the version that convinces me. The sourcing transparency is exactly what I needed. I was at neutral in V2; I'm at 'would sign up' now.
unanswered_questions: Who curates — is there an editorial team? How is organizer credibility assessed?
price_reaction: Would pay for genuine quality.

name: Olivia Santos
clarity_response: A curated NYC shortlist of 3-5 filtered activities — sourced beyond Eventbrite, filtered for quality, personalized by behavior.
strongest_line: We learn from what you skip.
what_feels_off: I want to drill into each recommendation before committing. The example card format is good but I'd want to know: can I see more detail per card? Reviews, photos, context?
objections: Detail level per card — the example format is clean but I want more depth when I'm actually choosing.
gut_reaction: The mechanism explanation changed my impression significantly. Knowing it learns from skip/save behavior, not social media, is exactly what I needed to hear. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Card detail depth, can I drill in, Flatbush coverage.
price_reaction: Would pay if quality is demonstrable.

name: Tara Patel
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist — no social media, no account required, sourced from beyond major platforms, first shortlist within 48 hours.
strongest_line: We'll send your first shortlist within 48 hours.
what_feels_off: The 48-hour promise changes everything for me. I deleted Instagram because I don't engage with low-quality signals. A 48-hour commitment means I'll know quickly if this is worth it or not.
objections: Very minor: I'd want to understand what happens if the 48-hour shortlist is bad. Is there a feedback mechanism?
gut_reaction: The 48-hour shortlist is the thing that pushed me from skeptic to sign-up. Concrete and testable. I'm in.
unanswered_questions: Feedback mechanism after first shortlist, Tribeca coverage.
price_reaction: Would pay after seeing the first shortlist.

name: Raj Patel
clarity_response: A curated NYC event shortlist sourced from beyond major platforms — gallery mailing lists, community boards, artist networks — not just filtered Eventbrite.
strongest_line: We source from everywhere Eventbrite doesn't.
what_feels_off: The Bronx textile show — that's the kind of thing I'd want to find. The Navy Yard theater — site-specific, non-Eventbrite. These are genuinely more obscure than V2. But 'would we go ourselves' is still a curatorial taste claim I can't verify.
objections: I can't verify the curators' taste matches mine without trying it. The sourcing is credible but taste alignment remains unproven.
gut_reaction: Better. The sourcing section and new example cards address my V2 critique directly. I'm moved from skeptical to 'would try.' Not fully converted but the 48-hour shortlist gives me a low-risk test.
unanswered_questions: Who is doing the curation? Is there editorial transparency? Upper East Side coverage.
price_reaction: Would try free tier. Would pay if taste proves aligned.

objections: Minor: 'would we go ourselves' — I want to know who 'we' is. A team with similar taste to mine? Editorial transparency would help.

objections: Still can't fully verify taste alignment before trying. But the 48-hour test is a reasonable way to find out.

name: Esme Blackwell
clarity_response: An intentional NYC event discovery tool — sourced from beyond Eventbrite, quality-filtered, with a shortlist of 3-5 genuinely worth-it picks.
strongest_line: Not on Eventbrite.

objections: Still want to see how this compares to Time Out over a month of use. But that's a product question, not a copy question.
gut_reaction: I'm in. The sourcing methodology and the genuinely obscure examples prove this is different from Time Out. I'd sign up right now.
unanswered_questions: Long Island City coverage, frequency of shortlists.
price_reaction: Would pay. This is worth money.

objections: Minor: I want to understand whether the shortlist reflects my taste or just general quality. Those are different things.
gut_reaction: Yes. The sourcing sourcing section proves they're doing something different. These example cards aren't filtered Eventbrite — they're genuinely beyond the obvious. I'd sign up.
unanswered_questions: Taste calibration vs general quality, Upper West Side coverage.

name: Ravi Krishnan
clarity_response: A curated NYC cultural shortlist — sourced from artist networks, gallery mailing lists, community boards — filtered for quality, not popularity.
strongest_line: We source from everywhere Eventbrite doesn't.

objections: Social proof demographic skew. Addressable but not a blocker.

objections: None. The sourcing list answers my V2 concern about unofficial and community events.

objections: None. 'Free to get started' answered the only question I had left.
gut_reaction: YES. Free to get started AND free events that are actually curated? I'm signing up right now and sending to every broke NYC friend I have.
unanswered_questions: Bushwick coverage, free event volume in the shortlist.

objections: Distance-to-free-event tradeoff. Transit cost makes a Bronx free event not free for someone in Crown Heights.
